thanks so much hi everybody can y'all hear me in the back there this is working okay
excellent excellent hi welcome isn't it lovely to be inside this nice warm dry
conference room instead of out in the blustery rain my name is Anne Jenna Vakeel you can find me on twitter at my
name because i am not good at coming up with clever cute internet handles and the slides for this talk are up on my
speaker deck you can find it at speaker deck comm slash Becky Leigh and then the language of programming talk in case you
want to look at any of the references which are all listed in the end and the talk I'm here to give today and and
hopefully the discussion that I'm here to open with all of you is about the language of programming so I'm a
software developer and educator I'm based out of San Francisco and like many
of us in the industry I do not have a background or a degree a formal education in computer science instead I
came to know and love the field of software development through the fields
of linguistics and computational linguistics so my background is in studying linguistics which is the
scientific study of human language and before I studied that I studied philosophy so I really like to get into
these like big huge philosophical questions like what even is code man and
I kind of laugh at myself and make fun of myself but I think it's really important that we do this from time to
time that we kind of take a step back and then we consider you know what are we even trying to do here when we sit
down and type these weird invitations into our computer that then magically
execute whatever we've told it to do and so I think that it's probably not very
controversial to say that code is somehow related to language right we use the word language and we talk about
programming languages we use a lot of language stick type metaphors when we talk about
code so I don't think it's a it's really going too far to say that it's somehow related to language or some type of
language and I used to think that it's it's kind of a language that we use to talk with machines unlike human language
that we use to talk to each other and to communicate with other humans we use programming languages to communicate
between me the coder and my computer so here I am over here smiling because I've
just had a brilliant idea and all I have to do is write down those weird magical
indications in some programming language save it to my 3.5 inch floppy disk insert that into the drive in my laptop
that I definitely have and then magically my idea comes to life the
computer does whatever I told it to do that's pretty cool and so I used to
think that this is that that is the kind of flow of information that I am using this programming language to talk to my
computer but recently I've started to wonder if that's actually even the case
and this is a question that's been raised for a long time by lots of folks is is really communicating with machines
the primary purpose of programming of writing code of developing programming languages and a lot of folks say no it's
not that's kind of a a nice side effect but really the core purpose is for us to
talk to other humans through the medium of our code so folks might be familiar
with SiC P structure and interpretation of computer programs really epic
introductory programming texts for out of MIT and in this great book one of the
many fabulous quotes is that they say a computer language is not just a way of
getting a computer to perform operations in fact it's a novel formal medium for
expressing ideas about methodology about how we want to solve a problem
and so thus they say programs must be written for people humans to read and
only incidentally for machines to execute so the primary purpose
of us writing this code is really to communicate our ideas about the metha
methodology we're using to solve a certain problem to other people and then
as an added bonus we get the computer to actually run through that methodology so
really we can think of coding not just as language for machines but first and foremost as a language we use to
communicate with other humans about doing things with computers so instead
of this kind of one-way flow of information from me to the computer instead what we start to see is a really
collaborative pattern where I have some idea about how I want to solve a
particular problem in a very structured methodological way I encode that in a
formal notation in my in my program in my code which then my teammate across
the room or perhaps some complete stranger across the world who checked out my github repo can read and
understand my mental model understand my ideas that I want to have the computer
do because that's how I'm trying to solve this problem and then both of us can work on that code together kind of
sync our mental models we can collaborate we can share our ideas encode them formally in this program
which serves not only as a communicative medium between us but then low and behold we can again put on that floppy
drive and give to the computer to actually run through in a way that we
have specified collaboratively so this is really if to my mind now kind of the
very very powerful thing about code it allows us to collaborate and in that
sense it's very similar to human language human language is so epically
powerful because it allows us to communicate with one another so that we can collaborate on whatever endeavor we
have in mind whether that be hunting a woolly mammoth or whether that be doing something completely audacious like
building a tower to reach heaven so if folks are familiar with the story of the
Tower of Babel the idea being that imagine a time when all of humanity
spoke a single language imagine the collaborative power that would give us
we could all work together all of us and direct all of our forces towards a
single project for example building this really big tower all the way up to
heaven and in the in the story it goes that that was so threatening apparently
so so dangerous of a possibility that even an omnipotent being God would feel like
like that might be a threat and so decided as the story goes to a split up
human languages so that we would no longer all be able to understand each other and undertake such audacious feats
now that is not the current accepted origin story of all the world's
different languages in the linguistic scientific community as I said linguistics is a science of language and
this is not exactly how they think we got all the different languages that we have today they think it has a lot more
to do with how we kind of evolved and moved around as a species but one way or another we ended up with a bunch of
different languages on this planet and so linguists seek to try to understand
the phenomena of human language by looking at each of its many different
faces and today we have something on about 7,000 different languages spoken
and used on the planet and so each of those 7,000 languages is a crucial piece
of the linguistic puzzle so linguists really value every single data point every single language that they can
study that they can understand that they can record as a crucial element of the
global overall picture of how language works for humans and so the field of
linguistic typology seeks to analyze different languages and understand how they compare and contrast in terms of
different features that those languages might have this is a map from a really
cool project called the world atlas of language structures and if you're ever curious about how
different features whether that be features of the sounds of language or features of the grammar and the syntax
of different languages how those compare globally definitely check out this world atlas of language structures it's a
really cool project where they break it down on lots of different levels and this particular visualization what we
can see is a subset of the world's languages just a few hundred about three hundred and some with the different
colored dots representing different ways that these languages handle a particular
feature or whether or not they have a particular feature in this case we're looking at a grammatical feature and in
particular the future we're looking at is whether or not the language has gender distinctions in personal pronouns
so English for example has a gender distinction he she they and singular pronouns but we don't have that
distinction in I or you or we right and what we can see through doing an
analysis like this which is so nicely visualized here is that even if many
languages share the same way of handling a particular phenomenon so many
languages might share a particular feature there still might be a handful or in some cases even one language that
does something typologically different and that is a really valuable piece of information all of these pieces of
information are valuable for example there's only one language in this study where they have distinction in the third
person but not in the singular only in the plural so it would be like she all
and he all or something like that and as we can see there are various other ways
of handling this phenomenon one other interesting thing to note here is that most the vast majority of languages in
this study 250 out of three ha 300 odd don't make any dejenne der distinctions
in pronouns at all so it's it's almost looking geographically it's almost like
that's kind of a largely Western phenomenon I'm just gonna point that out without further comment any who the
point is that to do linguistics linguists really need to take a look at all of these data points
and consider them globally and all of them are equally valuable for
understanding the overall picture and so what they will do is they will take a
particular language and deconstruct elements of that language to try to
understand the composition that makes them up so one level of analysis that
they might do this on is syntactic analysis so understanding the grammatical structure of phrases and
sentences this is the sentence you might have heard before colorless green ideas sleep furiously anybody recognize it
couple hands so this is a sentence made famous by Noam Chomsky in his seminal
and very influential work syntactic structures a book that came out in the 50s 57 I believe where he kind of
started linguistics down a path of really paying attention to syntax a lot
and to composing or understanding how sentences and phrases are composed of
these constituents these grammatical constituent phrases so here we're taking this sentence which is an example of a
sentence that's syntactically valid so grammatically okay but semantically in
terms of its meaning it doesn't really have any it doesn't really make sense colorless green ideas sleep furiously
not really a sentence you would expect anyone to say meaning wise but
grammatically it's perfectly fine and we can show that by showing how it breaks down into a noun phrase and a verb
phrase and how each of those phrases further break down perhaps into sub phrases and ultimately into individual
words with different parts of speech adjectives and verbs and nouns and adverbs and so this is one way that
linguists might try to deconstruct language to understand the underlying phenomena and this is just one level of
analysis that they might do that on they might do it on many other levels of abstraction both higher than the
sentence so things like in considering entire texts or considering entire dialogues between people
as conversations and understanding how conversations break down and how texts break down in terms of the discourse
used or they might look on a lower level they might work look at individual words and how those break down into sub word
units of meaning called morphemes or they might look at the level of sound how are the sounds of a word broken up
into syllables how are those broken up into individual sounds called phones and phonemes and
the point is that that they will need to kind of look at different levels of analysis to really understand the full
picture of how this language works now this reminds me a lot of the type of
work that we do as programmers we analyze our programs and break them down
on different levels of abstraction much like linguists do language so we look at
on the on the big lip picture we look at our systems in terms of their their components their services micro services
things like that and how all those pieces tie together we also sometimes look at an individual module of code and
understand how it's broken up into functions if we're doing functional programming perhaps or objects if we're
object-oriented programmers or sometimes we get much much lower level and we think about the individual instructions
that the computer would have to execute here or how all of these commands might break down into the individual bytes and
bits that the computer is actually able to speak as it were the point being in
both of these types of analysis linguistic and software analysis when we
do this type of deconstruction when we look at how our programs or our sentences are composed
we are relying on certain structures that are not objective things in the
world they're all parts of a theory that we have about what types of structures
exist or in some cases should exist in a language or in a program and which ones
are most important to pay attention to so for example Chomsky in his syntactic
structures placed a huge emphasis on looking at the the free level of the way sentences breakdown so
this syntactic analysis and posited these kind of trees and said that this
is how all language works it works really well for English but also made some assumptions that other linguists
disagree with so this is a quote from a linguist named Michael Tomasello from a
paper he wrote called language is not an instinct that was a response to a book
you all might have heard of called the language instinct by another linguist Steven Pinker what we're getting at is
like this epic war in linguistics that rages to this day between the kind of Chomsky and Pinker tradition that posits
a kind of that that language is this innate thing that we all have this innate structure for in our brains and
there are terms like universal grammar thrown around and we're not going to get into it unfortunately and then there are
other folks like Tomasello who take kind of more of a an approach of understanding language in terms of
general cognitive function and how humans approach cognition more generally
in languages being kind of a subset of that this is all to say there's this this kind of fundamental disagreement in
terms of what the structures are that we should be paying attention to and one
thing that I really like in in this paper by Thomas Selda he points out is he says that there are no theory neutral
structures in linguistics you can't say that noun phrases exists objectively
that is a theory you are using to apply to do this linguistic analysis it's not
a be-all end-all thing in the world it is a theory and there's no way to do any
kind of linguistic analysis without assuming some kind of underlying theory
some some kind of worldview of how language works and how it's broken up and this is true in programming as well
when we look at a system and we try to understand what are the units of
analysis here that are most meaningful that are most important for us to pay attention to we are assuming an
underlying theory or a worldview you might say of how programs are
what types of things they're made up of how those things behave and interact and we have a word for that type of theory
or worldview we call it a paradigm a programming paradigm is is a really
fascinating topic that I could nerd out about for an entire hour and in fact I did at this conference a couple years
ago so if you want to nerd out with me about programming paradigms you can
check out my talk programming across paradigms from go to Chicago 2017 but I
won't talk your ear off about it now I will just say however that it's really interesting to consider how our tools
are programming languages support or do not support different theoretical
constructs for what a program is or could or should be so this is a diagram
from a paper by a researcher named Peter van Roy he's a computer scientist who researches or has has written a lot
about programming paradigms and how they relate to problem solving which is what we're trying to do here as coders and he
says that every language realizes or supports we could say one or perhaps
multiple paradigms so you might have some languages like Haskell let's say that forced you to use a particular
paradigm functional programming in that case or you might have other languages like let's say Python that are much more
flexible that allow you to write imperative code or object oriented code or even functional code and so on and so
forth but he started looking at those paradigms and trying to deconstruct them even further and he posits that each
paradigm can actually be understood as a collection of concepts that it supports
for example does this paradigm allow state does it allow non determinism and
so on and so forth so these kind of fundamental building blocks these these questions that a paradigm has to answer
which when you take a bunch of building blocks and put them together you get kind of a theory of how a program works
or should work and he says that insofar
as it supports those different concepts each paradigm makes the best solution
for a particular type of problem so we can't
understand paradigms as good or bad objectively and by extension we can't
understand the languages that support those paradigms as good or bad objectively rather we have to understand
them in the context of a particular problem is this a good tool for solving this problem and what this brings to
mind for me is another word from linguistics and perhaps one of the one
of the core one of the like linguistics 101 like main ideas that you learn when
studying this is to avoid prescriptivism
prescriptivism or a prescriptive comment about a language would be saying how
language should be versus a descriptive comment would be saying how language is
without making any kind of value judgment about whether that's good or bad so you might have heard a
prescriptive statement something like hmm is not is the correct form and you
should not say eight eight is wrong should say is not linguists have no time
for that kind of thing they are not interested in saying how someone should
talk there is no should in linguistics linguists are interested in making descriptive analyses of when someone
might use the is not form or the eight form or in what context or why or how
they're interested in understanding how this occurs and in in what situations
and so any form of a language that is used to communicate between people is

are called array programming languages they have a particular focus or are

that differ radically among different cultures as we can see in the atlas of language structures earlier and
languages change in important ways as the communicative needs of their speakers evolved over time so languages

community develop different needs as our problems change we're going to have to evolve our tools to match those needs
and so this all gets at this idea that
is a really important one in certain subfields of linguistics that we need to
understand language in the wider context it exists in for example the field of
sociolinguistics studies how language exists not in
isolation not Chomsky sitting in an armchair thinking up sentences that may or may not be possible but rather how
language exists in the wider socio-cultural context language is
something that we do as a human activity that is inextricably intertwined with
all of our other human activities and all of the dynamics involved so we can't
separate language from dynamics of power and status from notions of economic and
political systems from issues of race and gender and identity from systems of
religion and family dynamics there is no way to separate language language from
any of those it is deeply linked with all of those and every other word that
wouldn't fit on this slide all of those systems and make no mistake about it
insofar as code is a human activity code is inextricably intertwined to all of
these as well and so what we need to do as a community of programmers and of
computer scientists is consider our code in that wider social context
another interesting field that that considers language in context is pragmatics so in the field of pragmatics
we're looking at the use of language we're looking at how language is actually used to do things or to have
kind of communicative actions in the world and so what we quickly see is that words do not just exist in isolation in
in these kind of like Platonic ideal forms they are things we do in the world every time I say something I'm making an
action and I really need to consider not just kind of the the textbook meaning of
the words I use or what I had in mind when I used a certain word I also need
to consider what impact that action that word that I'm using or that sentence
that I'm uh turing is going to have on the world around me sometimes that
impact can be a negative one the words that we use in our programs are no
different from words that we use in human language they are actions and they have impact as well this is a tweet from
a software developer named kaya Thomas who a few years ago was still in school
and mentioned that in her security class there was a lesson where they were

as a person learning about this in this class and evoked also to her mind the
other other very impactful and negatively impactful words that we use in code without really considering the
